According, then, to Savigny, Quorum bonorum was a definitive suit in matters of succession when the plaintiff, instead of claiming hereditas in reliance 011 jus civile, claimed bonorum possessio in 'reliance on jus praetorium. But the prevalent opinion is that of Vangerow, that Quorum bonorum was merely a summary and provisional procedure for obtaining possession pending the defini- tive suit for the succession. Such possession was defensible (sine re) by an adverse decision of the final suit, which, if the succession was by civil law, would be hereditatis petitio; if it was merely praetorian‚ as founded on cognatio svo„ hereditatis petitio possessoria, Dig. 5, 5, 1. In support of this view, it may be observed that on Savigny’s hypothesis no satisfactory account can be given of the nature of hereditatis petitio possessoris..
